repnme.cdata!:
Guinea - Second, Third, and Fourth
            Structural Adjustment; Public Enterprise Sector
            Rationalization & Privatization Technical Assistance;
            and Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The five projects examined for Guinea,
            the Second, Third, And Fourth Structural Adjustment, Public
            Enterprise Sector Rationalization & Privatization
            Technical Assistance, and Financial Sector Adjustment
            Credits have outcomes ranging from moderately unsatisfactory
            to unsatisfactory.  In all projects the sustainability is
            unlikely and Bank and Borrower's performances are
            considered highly unsatisfactory with modest or negligible
            institutional development. The main lessons derived from
            these operations for the Bank are: adjustment lending
            operations should be underpinned by a high quality and
            adequate economic and sector work program; time-bound,
            monitorable indicators should be used to verify performance;
            both revenue and expenditure issues should be addressed in
            reducing fiscal deficits; single tranche credits should be
            used only when the government has an established track
            record of good policy performance; IDA staff re-assignments
            should not be disruptive to IDA operations and client
            relations; timely warning should be given to management and
            the Board of rising IDA risk exposure from an unsustainable
            debt burden; and donor lending can create incentives to
            mismanage the economy

repnme.cdata!: Guinea - Financial Sector Adjustment Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Financial Sector
            Adjustment Credit in Guinea is considered unsatisfactory
            with poor performance by both the Bank and the Borrower and
            uncertain sustainability. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project: a) to ensure successful implementation, a
            project has to be kept simple, well focused and have well
            identified priorities; b) the capacity of the borrower to
            implement a project should be correctly assessed and
            measures to reinforce it, if needed, taken well before
            project effectiveness; c) a thorough participatory approach
            in project preparation is paramount to ensure project
            ownership, understanding of its objectives, and proper
            identification of potential implementation problems; d)
            reform of the judicial system alone will not achieve any
            significant results, without proof of government enforcment
            the laws and elimination of corruption; e) an adjustment
            operation, due to its short duration, is not a suitable
            vehicle to address judicial system reforms; and f)
            restructuring and recapitilizing troubled banks without
            changing their ownership is a bad idea because it does not
            deal with the cause of the problems.

18154246.subsc: Non-comp pens/ins,Other Finance,Banking,Law and justice,Central government administration
18154246.theme: International financial standards and systems,Regulation and competition policy,Other economic management,Macroeconomic management,Debt management and fiscal sustainability
18154246.trustfund: TF028001-FAC CONSULTANT TRUST FUND,TF028021-WATER & SANITATION INVEST. PROJ.
18154246.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Economic management

abstracts.cdata!:
The Financial Sector Operations Credit
            project will support a multi-faceted financial sector
            operation to be undertaken in the context of the
            country's medium-term economic program. The
            operation's objectives are: 1) strengthen the monetary,
            regulatory, supervisory, and judicial environment; 2)
            develop a bridge between the informal and formal sectors to
            increase the reach of the financial sector; and 3) build
            upon the human resource base and improve institutional
            capacity. The Government will contribute to the development
            of indirect instruments of monetary management such as open
            market operations, disengage from the capital and management
            of financial institutions, adopt regulation for all
            categories of financial institutions, reinforce supervision
            mechanisms, and take measures to improve the judicial system
            in its enforcement of financial contracts and the recovery
            of bad debt. To build a bridge between the formal and
            informal sectors, the system of mutualistic savings and loan
            institutions will be extended in rural areas, and a new
            system will be introduced in Conakry. Institution building
            will focus on: 1) improving the capacity of the Central Bank
            to conduct monetary policy and supervise and restructure
            financial institutions; 2) building the capacity within the
            Ministry of Finance to monitor and analyze financial sector
            developments; 3) strengthening the Ministry of Justice and
            the court system; and 4) training commerical bank and
            insurance company staff, as well as members of the legal profession.
